Legal_Issue: Can the availability of citizenship in a safe country bar a refugee claim?
Evidence_Type: Official advice from Venezuelan Embassy, Venezuelan Constitution, marital status documentation
Legal_Provision: Section 97(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Availability of Venezuelan citizenship through marriage
Regulation_Cited: IRPR Section 2.02(1), Article 34 of the Venezuelan Constitution
Legal_Standard: Whether the claimant has a viable alternative protection option
Application_Factor: Marriage to a Venezuelan citizen enabling access to citizenship
Decision_Review_Issue: Was the Boardâ€™s interpretation of eligibility for refugee protection reasonable?
Governing_Rule_or_Provision: Citizenship in another country can bar a refugee claim if it is within the claimant's control and not subject to administrative discretion.
Cause_of_Refusal: Applicant could obtain Venezuelan citizenship and thus had an alternative source of protection
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Claimant argued lack of active pursuit of citizenship negates availability
Jurisdictional_Focus: Canada, with reference to Venezuela and Colombia
Relevant_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Venezuelan Constitution
